title: This Pear Tallow Balm Was Weird. Then My Skin Stopped Freaking Out.
body:
Look. My face last month. It was a whole situation. Red patches by my nose. This tight, itchy feeling all the time, like my skin was shrink-wrapped. Winter just decided to park itself on my cheeks. I tried everything. The fancy La Mer cream my sister swore by? Felt like I was smearing cold butter. Didn’t do anything. The CeraVe in the tub from CVS? Better, but still. My skin would drink it up and be thirsty again in like, two hours. I was at the point where I’d just rub a little olive oil on my hands before bed because I was desperate. It was a mess.

Then I saw this thing online. A tallow balm. Beef tallow. For your face. I stared at my phone. Beef fat. You’re putting beef fat on your skin. I mean, come on. It sounded like something my great-grandmother would have used before they invented, you know, actual skincare. But the person talking about it seemed normal. And my skin was so mad at me. So I figured, what’s the worst that could happen? I ordered the pear-scented one from this little Etsy shop because if I was gonna smear animal fat on myself, I at least wanted it to smell like fruit. My total was like $28-something. I got the notification while I was waiting for my oil change. The guy at Jiffy Lube asked if I was okay because I was just frowning at my screen.

## How Beef Tallow for Skin Even Became a Thing I Tried

It arrived in a week. Small jar. The label was simple. It said it was whipped tallow from grass-fed cows, made in France. The texture was… weird. Not bad weird. It was solid but soft, like cold buttercream frosting. You scoop a tiny bit and it melts the second it hits your finger. I was skeptical. Deeply skeptical. I put the jar on my nightstand and ignored it for two days. Every time I saw it I’d think, “beef fat.” But my face was still that tight, uncomfortable texture. So one night, after my shower, I just went for it.

I warmed a little dab between my fingers. It smelled… nice? Like a pear Jolly Rancher, but not sugary. Just a clean, light fruity smell. Nothing gross. I patted it on my dry patches first, then just smoothed a tiny bit over the rest of my face. It felt… oily for a second. But then it wasn’t. It just sank in. Gone. My skin felt calm. Not greasy. Just quiet. I went to bed expecting to wake up a pizza. I didn’t.

## What This Pear Tallow Balm Actually Does (Or, What It Did For Me)

The next morning was the real test. My skin wasn’t red. The tight feeling was gone. It just felt like skin. Normal, hydrated skin. I was shocked. I kept using it. Morning and night. Just a tiny bit. That little jar lasts forever. Here’s the thing I didn’t get at first: tallow is supposed to be really close to the oils our own skin makes. So it doesn’t just sit on top. It gets in there. My skin stopped freaking out because it was finally getting what it actually needed, not some fancy chemical cocktail it didn’t understand.

My hands were a disaster too. From washing them all the time, the knuckles were cracked and rough. I started using the balm on them. It fixed that in like, three days. No joke. My elbows haven’t been this smooth since I was a kid. I don’t have psoriasis, but I’ve read that this stuff is supposed to be really good for it because it’s so healing and non-irritating. I believe it.

Oh, random tangent. The other night I was putting it on and my cat, Mochi, jumped up and tried to sniff my face. He just sat there purring. He usually hates lotion smells. Maybe he thinks I smell like a nice steak now. I don’t know. Anyway, my coffee’s getting cold.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

So it’s been a few weeks now. Maybe a month? I lost track. I’m still using it. My skin is just… stable. It’s not a miracle. I didn’t turn into a glowing goddess. But the problems I had? The dry patches, the irritation, the winter face? Gone. It’s just gone. My skin feels resilient. Like it can handle the cold wind now. I used to have these little fine lines around my eyes that would look worse when I was dehydrated. They’re still there, but they’re less… dramatic. They just look like my face, not a problem to be fixed.

I wore it under my makeup once. It worked fine. Didn’t pill or anything. Mostly I just use it at night. It’s become this little ritual. I wash my face, put on this balm, and that’s it. My skincare routine is now one step. I love that. No ten-step process. No waiting for serums to dry. Just one thing that works.

## Would I Buy This Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. I’m on my second jar. I got one for my mom too, for her rough hands. She called me last week and was like, “What is this magic butter?” She loves it. I’m not a skincare expert. I’m just a person whose skin was being difficult and found something that made it stop. It’s simple. It’s natural skincare in the most literal sense. It’s just one ingredient, whipped up with some essential oil for scent.

If you’re staring at your own angry, dry skin and nothing is working, this might be worth a shot. It sounds weird. It is weird. But it works. I don’t know how else to say it. My skin is happy. I’m happy. That’s the whole review.

I got mine from **PureNatureTallow** on Etsy. The shop was nice, shipping was quick. No fuss.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Seems to be, yeah. The science-y reason is that it’s really similar to the sebum our skin already produces, so it absorbs deeply and doesn’t just clog stuff up. It’s like giving your skin back what it’s lost.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores easy. Because it mimics skin oil, it absorbs properly. It doesn’t feel like it’s sitting on top of my skin at all. It just… disappears and does its job.

**What does the pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s a light, fresh smell. Like a real pear, not candy. It’s not strong at all. Fades pretty quick after you put it on. Just leaves your skin feeling good, not perfumed.

Anyway. If your skin’s being a jerk this winter, maybe give tallow a look. It’s just one jar. Might fix your whole thing.
